question:
Select the grammatically correct sentence.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 14 July Shift-1)
option_1: The participants of the competition is waiting for their turn curiously.
option_2: The participants of the competition are waiting for their turn curiously.
option_3: The participants of the competition has been waiting for their turn curiously.
option_4: A participants of the competition is waiting for their turn curiously.
solution:
Answer: The participants of the competition are waiting for their turn curiously.

Solution:

  • "Participants" is a plural subject, so it requires a plural verb.

  • "Are waiting" is the correct plural verb in present continuous tense.

  • "Is waiting" is incorrect because "is" is singular and doesnâ€™t agree with the plural subject.

  • "Has been waiting" is also singular; for plural, it should be "have been waiting".

  • "A participants" is grammatically incorrect because "a" is used for singular nouns, but "participants" is plural.

  • Participants means people who take part â€“ à¤­à¤¾à¤— à¤²à¥‡à¤¨à¥‡ à¤µà¤¾à¤²à¥‡ à¤²à¥‹à¤—

  • Competition means a contest â€“ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾

  • Curiously means with eagerness or interest â€“ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¸à¥‡

question:

solution:
Correct Answer: No substitution

Solution:
The sentence "Either the bears or the lion has escaped from the zoo." is grammatically correct.

When using "Either...or", the verb agrees with the subject closer to it (in this case, "the lion", which is singular).
So we use "has escaped" (singular) â€” not "have" or "are".

Options (1), (2), and (3) are incorrect due to:

  • Wrong verb agreement (have is plural),

  • Incorrect verb form (is escaped, are escaped are grammatically wrong in this context).

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If no substitution is required, select â€˜No substitutionâ€™.
Fifty litres of milk aÌ²rÌ²eÌ² Ì²dÌ²oÌ²nÌ²aÌ²tÌ²eÌ²dÌ² Ì²bÌ²yÌ² Ì²tÌ²hÌ²eÌ² Ì²cÌ²oÌ²mÌ²mÌ²iÌ²tÌ²tÌ²eÌ²eÌ² to the orphanage every week.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 18 August Shift 3 (3 to 4 PM))
option_1: are donated by a committee
option_3: are being donated by the committee
option_4: is donated by the committee
solution:
Answer: is donated by the committee

Solution:

  • Subjectâ€“verb agreement:

  • The subject is â€œFifty litres of milkâ€. Although it contains a plural noun (â€œlitresâ€), it denotes a single measured quantity of an uncountable noun (â€œmilkâ€), and so takes a singular verb (â€œisâ€).

  • Mass noun concept:

  • Mass nouns (like milk, water, information) refer to substances that arenâ€™t counted individually. When you quantify them (â€œlitres of milkâ€), English treats the entire phrase as one unit.

  • Collective noun usage:

  • â€œThe committeeâ€ is a collective nounâ€”a group regarded as a single entityâ€”and thus pairs with a singular verb in this context.

question:

The subject of the sentence is "The famous actor," which is singular. The phrase "along with his close family members" is a parenthetical phrase and does not change the singular subject to plural.

Therefore, the verb should be singular to agree with the singular subject:

  • was attending â€“ âœ… Correct singular past continuous form.

  • has attending â€“ âŒ Incorrect verb form.

  • are attending â€“ âŒ Plural verb, does not agree with singular subject.

  • am attending â€“ âŒ Incorrect subject-verb agreement and person.

So, the correct substitution is "was attending."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select â€˜No substitutionâ€™.
Music sÌ²oÌ²oÌ²tÌ²hÌ²eÌ²sÌ² Ì²aÌ²nÌ²dÌ² Ì²rÌ²eÌ²lÌ²iÌ²eÌ²vÌ²eÌ²sÌ² you of any stress and negative emotions.

 The original sentence â€” "Music soothes and relieves you of any stress and negative emotions." â€” is grammatically correct.

 Letâ€™s look at why the other options are incorrect:
Would soothes and relief â€“ Incorrect: "would" should be followed by the base verb (i.e., soothe), and "soothes" is incorrect here; "relief" is a noun, not a verb.

Therefore, the sentence is already correct.
No substitution is needed.

question:

question:
Select the option that can substitute the bracketed word segment correctly and complete the following sentence meaningfully.
Lots of kids (was visualised) crossing the road when the bus arrived.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 3 Oct Shift-1 (9 to 11 AM))
solution:
the correct answer is â€œwere seenâ€

lots of kids is in Plural form So, helping verb should be in plural form.

Therefore, "Lots of kids were seen crossing the road when the bus arrived" is the most appropriate and grammatically correct choice, conveying the intended meaning that people observed the kids crossing the road in the past.

question:
Select the word segment which substitutes the bracketed word correctly and completes the sentence meaningfully.
Mathematics (are not) easy to learn.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 4_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: 4
Solution: The correct substitution is "is not."

Mathematics is treated as a singular subject, so it takes the singular verb "is."
The sentence becomes:
"Mathematics is not easy to learn."

Why other options are incorrect:

  • has not âŒ: incorrect auxiliary verb for this context.

  • were not âŒ: plural past tense, does not match singular subject.

  • was not âŒ: singular past tense; while grammatically possible, the present tense "is not" fits better generally.

Therefore, "is not" is the most appropriate choice.

question:

Every nook and corner oÌ²fÌ² Ì²tÌ²hÌ²eÌ² Ì²hÌ²oÌ²uÌ²sÌ²eÌ² Ì²wÌ²eÌ²rÌ²eÌ² Ì²uÌ²nÌ²cÌ²lÌ²eÌ²aÌ²nÌ².Ì²

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 5 Dec Shift-3)
option_1: of the house was unclean
option_2: by the house were unclean
option_3: of a house was unclean

Explanation:

  • The phrase â€œEvery nook and cornerâ€ is treated as a singular entity, so it takes the singular verb was, not were.

  • â€œof the house was uncleanâ€ correctly matches the singular verb to the singular subject.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Health insurance aÌ²rÌ²eÌ² Ì²iÌ²mÌ²pÌ²oÌ²rÌ²tÌ²aÌ²nÌ²tÌ² today since anyone can face a medical emergency without warning.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 5 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The correct option is: is important

When the subject is singular, the corresponding verb should also be singular. In this case, "health insurance" is indeed a singular noun, so the appropriate verb should be singular as well. Therefore, "is important" is the correct choice

Therefore, the correct answer is: â€œHealth insurance is important today since anyone can face a medical emergency without warning.â€

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select â€˜No substitution requiredâ€™.
Larger emissions of greenhouse gases lÌ²eÌ²aÌ²dÌ² Ì²tÌ²oÌ² Ì²hÌ²iÌ²gÌ²hÌ²eÌ²rÌ² Ì²cÌ²oÌ²nÌ²cÌ²eÌ²nÌ²tÌ²rÌ²aÌ²tÌ²iÌ²oÌ²nÌ²sÌ² in the atmosphere.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 8_Sept_Shift-1)
option_1: have lead to higher concentrations
option_3: is lead to higher concentrations
solution:
Answer: (4) No substitution required
Solution:
â€¢ The sentence is: "Larger emissions of greenhouse gases lead to higher concentrations in the atmosphere."
â€¢ The verb "lead" is in the simple present tense, which is correct here because the sentence describes a general scientific fact or repeated occurrence
â€¢ The subject "Larger emissions" is plural, so the verb "lead" (plural form) correctly agrees with it
â€¢ The phrase "lead to higher concentrations" is both grammatically and contextually accurate

Other options explained:
â€¢ have lead to â€“ incorrect; should be "have led to" if using present perfect
â€¢ leaded to â€“ grammatically incorrect; "leaded" is not the past tense of "lead" (correct is "led")
â€¢ is lead to â€“ wrong verb form and mismatched subject-verb agreement

Hence, the original sentence is correct and needs no substitution â€“ Option (4) âœ…

question:
Select the word segment that substitutes (replaces) the bracketed word segment correctly and completes the sentence meaningfully.
Neither the teachers (or the principal likes the new budget) cuts.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 9 Dec Shift-4)
option_1: nor the principal like the new budget
option_2: either the principal likes the new budget
option_3: nor the principal likes the new budget
option_4: or the principal like the new budget
solution:
Answer: nor the principal likes the new budget

Explanation:
In English, when two subjects are joined by neitherâ€¦nor, the verb agrees with the nearest subject. Here, â€œprincipalâ€ is singular, so we need the singular verb likes. Option 3 restores the correct conjunction and agreement, yielding:

â€œNeither the teachers nor the principal likes the new budget cuts.â€

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select â€˜No substitution requiredâ€™.
He and his father Ì²tÌ²aÌ²kÌ²eÌ² Ì²aÌ² Ì²rÌ²iÌ²dÌ²eÌ² every morning to the top of the hill.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: 2 (No substitution required)

Solution:
The sentence is:
"He and his father take a ride every morning to the top of the hill."

  • The subject is â€œHe and his fatherâ€, which is a compound subject (plural).

  • Therefore, the verb should be â€œtakeâ€, not â€œtakesâ€ (which is singular).

  • The article â€œaâ€ is correctly used with the noun â€œrideâ€ (a countable noun starting with a consonant sound).

âœ” So, the sentence is grammatically correct as written, and no substitution is needed.

Why other options are incorrect:
Takes a ride â€“ incorrect because the subject is plural.
Taking a ride â€“ incorrect tense and structure for this sentence.
Takes an ride â€“ incorrect article usage; â€œrideâ€ begins with a consonant sound, so â€œaâ€ is correct, not â€œanâ€.
